docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnant women diagnosed with breast cancer once felt they had to choose either the toxic doses of chemotherapy or a healthy baby, but never both. Now they may be able to use a standard chemotherapy to treat their malignancies, and still look forward to safe deliveries and healthy infants, a recent study published in the current issue of the Journal of Clinical Oncology has found.

headline.main: Cancer Regimen Found Safe in Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Researchers report that pregnant women diagnosed with breast cancer may be able to use standard chemotherapy to treat malignancies and still look forward to safe deliveries and healthy infants; say, contrary to popular belief, chemotherapy can be used in second and third trimesters with minimal or no complications of labor or delivery (S)
docs.snippet: Pregnant women diagnosed with breast cancer once felt they had to choose either the toxic doses of chemotherapy or a healthy baby, but never both.    Now they may be able to use a standard chemotherapy to treat their malignancies,  and still look...

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. The new supplement Cellasene claims to reduce cellulite, the fatty deposits that make the hips, thighs and buttocks look lumpy. Can this work? ALISHA BERGER I do cosmetic surgery for a living so I see a lot of women for liposuction. And when I first heard about this I was skeptical. The four active ingredients -- lipovascolen (TM), borage, fish oil and soya lecithin -- have been used and studied in Europe for many years.

headline.main: Fat-Gobbling Pill: Too Good to Be True?

docs.abstract: Dr George Beraka says that a new supplement Cellasene can reduce cellulite, fatty deposits that make hips, thighs and buttocks look lumpy; Dr Darrick E Antell says it cannot (S)
docs.snippet: Q. The new supplement Cellasene claims to reduce cellulite, the fatty deposits that make the hips, thighs and buttocks look lumpy. Can this work?   ALISHA BERGER      I do cosmetic surgery for a living so I see a lot of women for liposuction. And...

docs.lead_paragraph: Barbara Stevens swims 40 minutes every day in a flume, a pool no bigger than a sport utility vehicle that functions as a kind of aquatic treadmill. A lifelong swimmer with artificial hip and knee joints, Mrs. Stevens, 67, bought her flume in 1992 and installed the 7-by-15-foot pool in the side garden of her home in San Francisco. ''You are 'on' all the time,'' Mrs. Stevens said about swimming in place against the steady current the flume provides. ''Your mind gets in the mode of swimming.''

headline.main: Swimming Miles Without Moving an Inch

docs.abstract: Article on increasing use of flumes, small swimming pool that functions as kind of aquatic treadmill, to train athletes, surgery patients or exercise enthusiast; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Last Dec. 15, when a 29-year-old man serving time at the Nottoway Correctional Center in Virginia became ill with muscle pains, vomiting and abdominal cramps, he was simply given an aspirin substitute. But over the next few days his symptoms worsened: pain and tremors developed in his right arm, and he had trouble walking. Three days after visiting the prison clinic, he was taken to a hospital in Richmond, with a fever of 103 degrees. Within hours, he began to hallucinate, and he became agitated and disoriented. He also started to salivate copiously.

headline.main: A Bat's Swift Bite, Unfelt, That Could Bring Rabies

docs.abstract: Bats infect humans with rabies often without their victims knowing that that they have been bitten or scratched; silver-haired bat and eastern pipestrelle bat are predominant cause of disease among Americans; close encounters with bats should be followed immediately by vaccination; photo; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Circumcision of infant boys has alternately been called ''the unkindest cut'' and the key to good penile health and hygiene. Which is correct, and how does a parent with a newborn son make the decision? Those who have looked to the nation's pediatric authorities for guidance are no doubt thoroughly confused by now. The American Academy of Pediatrics has revised its policy on infant circumcision four times in three decades, with the latest word coming this month in an eight-page statement published in Pediatrics, the academy's journal.

headline.main: A Guide for Perplexed Parents Weighing Circumcision

docs.abstract: Jane Brody's Personal Health column offers advice for perplexed parents weighing circumcision (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many drugs carry consumer warnings: Avoid overexposure to the sun; do not drink alcohol, or take caution when operating machinery. But doctors may soon be offering a very different caveat when prescribing fluoroquinolone antibiotics, commonly used to treat urinary tract, bronchopulmonary or intestinal infections. Engaging in high-impact exercise or strenuous weightlifting while taking these drugs may lead to tendon ruptures, injuries that can require surgery and months of rehabilitation.
docs.abstract: Doctors may soon be offering new warning when prescribing fluoroquinolone antibiotics, commonly used to treat certain infections; say engaging in high-impact exercise while taking them can lead to tendon ruptures that can require surgery and months of rehabilitation; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Many drugs carry consumer warnings:  Avoid overexposure to the sun; do not drink alcohol, or take caution when operating machinery. But doctors may soon be offering a very different caveat when prescribing fluoroquinolone antibiotics, commonly used...

docs.lead_paragraph: Cervical cancer, curable if detected early, kills more women in the developing world than any other cancer for the lack of a simple, inexpensive and effective screening method. But researchers in Zimbabwe believe they have found just that, in vinegar, a trained eye and a flashlight. Reporting in the current issue of The Lancet, researchers said they simply swabbed a woman's cervix with acetic acid (vinegar) and a minute later looked to see if some cells had turned white, an indication of the presence of precancerous lesions caused by the human papilloma virus.
docs.abstract: Researchers in Zimbabwe say swabbing woman's cervix with acetic acid or vinegar and looking to see if cells turn white may be simple, inexpensive and simple screening method for cervical cancer in third world (M)
